bioghist.p: Anne d'Harnoncourt (1944-2008) headed the Philadelphia Museum of Art (PMA) as the George D. Widener Director from 1982 to 2008, adding the position of CEO in 1997. At the time of the latter appointment, d'Harnoncourt, then 53, was the only woman in America directing a museum with a budget of more than $25 million, making her, according to the New York Times, one of the most powerful women in the American art world. Under her directorship, the Museum has attracted a growing public audience through major "blockbuster" exhibitions and publications, and she has been credited with building a distinguished professional staff. Under her directorship, significant gallery renovations have been made, encompassing the 90 European art galleries and 20 galleries of modern and contemporary art. The changes to the European spaces also afforded the opportunity to reexamine, conserve and present in new ways thousands of objects in the collection. Under d'Harnoncourt's directorship, the Museum has also committed itself to the most ambitious expansion and renovation program in its more than 125-year history. Launched in 1999, this ten-year, $500 million capital plan includes increasing the Museum’s public space by sixty percent. Another significant goal of the program was realized in 2007 with the opening of the Perelman Building, a renovated Art Deco facility that offers additional gallery and office spaces across the street from the Museum’s iconic Neoclassical building. D'Harnoncourt's indelible association with the Museum began in 1967 when she worked for two years as a curatorial assistant in the Department of Painting and Sculpture. She spent the next two years as an Assistant Curator of Twentieth Century Art at the Art Institute of Chicago. In 1971 d'Harnoncourt returned to PMA as Associate Curator of Twentieth Century Art, becoming full Curator the following year. At this time, d'Harnoncourt's reputation as an expert on the art of Marcel Duchamp was truly taking form. In 1972 she organized a major retrospective of his work, which also traveled to the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Art Institute of Chicago. During her curatorial tenure at PMA, she championed the Museum's commitment to strengthen its contemporary art holdings, bringing in major works by Jasper Johns, Brice Marden, Ellsworth Kelly, Sol LeWitt and other important modern and contemporary artists. D'Harnoncourt's ties to the Museum are also personal. Her husband is Joseph Rishel, the Museum's Gisela and Dennis Alter Senior Curator of Euopean Painting before 1900 and Senior Curator of the John G. Johnson Collection and the Rodin Museum. They met while working at the Art Institute of Chicago, and married in 1971. Born in Washington D.C, d'Harnoncourt was raised in New York City, attending the Brearley School from 1949 to 1961. Her training in art history and museum studies came formally and informally. Her father, the distinguished art historian René d'Harnoncourt, served as director of the Museum of Modern Art in New York from 1949 until shortly before his death in 1968. His years there allowed d'Harnoncourt, as she describes, time for "scampering down the halls of the Museum…as a child." According to d'Harnoncourt, however, the more significant influence was her father's "enormous love of art and artists. He had a great respect and love for the art of installation." His circle of acquaintances also brought his daughter in contact with some of contemporary art's key figures, such as Jasper Johns and Mark Rothko. Her parents also knew Marcel Duchamp. Despite the early exposure, d'Harnoncourt never considered a museum career as a child; instead, she has said that she envisioned herself as an actress, or in government. She changed her mind after college. Upon graduating magna cum laude from Radcliffe College with a degree in history and literature, d'Harnoncourt attended London's Courtauld Institute, an experience she attributes as giving her "a marvelous kind of immersion in the history of art." In preparing her thesis, which examined the moral subject matter of 19th century British painting, particularly the art of the Pre-Raphaelites, d'Harnoncourt worked six months at the Tate Gallery, London. She received an M.A. with distinction from the Institute in 1967. Among d'Harnoncourt's writings are articles on 20th century artists and collectors of modern art for various journals, including the Museum’s 1969 Bulletin, which was devoted entirely to the 52-page essay she co-wrote with Walter Hopps about Duchamp's mixed-media assemblage, Etant Donnés. She also edited the 1973 publication, "Marcel Duchamp," wrote parts of the catalogue to the 1972-1973 exhibition, and contributed essays to the 1980 exhibition catalogue, "Futurism and the international avant-garde." Since becoming Director, d'Harnoncourt has written introductions and forewords to many of the Museum's publications. D'Harnoncourt has served on a number of panels, boards and committees at various times, including the J. Paul Getty Museum, the John Cage Trust, ARTstor, the Japan Society, the Henry Luce Foundation, Inc., University of Pennsylvania School of Design, the Fairmount Park Art Association, the Fabric Workshop and Museum, the Philadelphia Award, the National Endowment for the Arts, the Smithsonian Institution, and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden. She is a member of the Association of Art Museum Directors and of the American Philosophical Society, the country’s first learned society established by Benjamin Franklin in Philadelphia. She has received several citations and awards for herself and on behalf of the Museum from the City of Philadelphia and the State of Pennsylvania. The Republic of France has twice honored d'Harnoncourt, appointing her Chevalier and then Officier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres in 1995 and 2002, respectively. In 1997 d'Harnoncourt received the Philadelphia Award. Almost half a century earlier that same honor went to another of the Museum's directors, Fiske Kimball, whose 25-year tenure and legacy at the Museum d'Harnoncourt now rivals. In 2001, the Historical Society of Pennsylvania selected her for its Founder's Award for Exemplary Service to History, and in 2005 she received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Princeton University. In 2007 the President of Mexico awarded her the decoration of the Mexican Order of the Aztec Eagle. D'Harnoncourt's parents married in 1933 in Chicago. She was their only child. Her mother, Sarah Carr d'Harnoncourt, died in 2001.

scopecontent.p: More than half of these records (55 linear feet) consist of alphabetically arranged correspondence and subject files for the years 1982-2002, and thus begin approximately with d'Harnoncourt's appointment as Director. Currently, these files are subdivided by date spans of one to six years, with some subgroup dates overlapping. The 1995-1998 set is further divided into three subsets: alphabetical correspondence, departmental, and subject files. In the other sets, these records are interfiled in one alphabetical run. Exhibition records comprise another significant group, totaling 35 linear feet, dating from 1978 to 2006. The records begin with the 1982 exhibition, "Thomas Eakins: Artist of Philadelphia." To date, the latest exhibition documented is "Looking at Atget," which was held in 2005. The show featured the works of the French photographer Eugène Atget, who began his career in the early 1890s. Other separate filing groups pertain to d'Harnoncourt's affiliation with other organizations and to the Board of Trustees of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, which she joined in 1974. Measuring 1.3 linear feet, the former set of files is dated 1974-1980 and thus documents d'Harnoncourt's professional affiliations prior to her appointment as director. Records comprising the latter set are dated 1982-1986, and measure approximately 2.5 linear feet. Both sets of files were part of the first group of d'Harnoncourt's director's records (9 linear feet of records) accessioned by the Museum's Archives. Also of note is the set of files documenting the Museum's accreditation by the American Association of Museums (AAM). The material dates from 1999 and measures approximately 1.3 linear feet. The accreditation is a significant achievement for a museum in the United States. According to AAM, this "seal of approval" gives national recognition to an instiution's "commitment to excellence, accountability, high professional standards, and continued institutional improvement."

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
